intro: Tapinanthus adolfi-friderici, commonly known as the parasitic flowering plant or African dodder, is a hemiparasitic plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is native to regions of Africa, particularly in the savannas and woodlands. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers and has a fibrous, root-like structure that attaches to host roots. It is often found parasitizing various shrubs and trees, contributing to the ecological dynamics of its habitat. Its unique parasitic nature and lack of photosynthetic ability make it an interesting subject in botanical studies.
